title: Live - Hard Rock Fest, Atlanta  1999 ak320
description:
Live - Hard Rock Fest, Atlanta  1999 ak320

LĪVE is an American rock band from York, Pennsylvania, consisting of Ed Kowalczyk (vocals,  guitar,), Chad Taylor (lead guitar, vocals), Patrick Dahlheimer (bass) and Chad Gracey (drums). Kowalczyk left in 2009  but rejoined in December 2016.

Live got fame from 1994 album, Throwing Copper, which sold eight million copies in the U.S. They  had  hit singles in the 90s including "Lightning Crashes", which stayed on top of the  chart for 10 consecutive weeks and the Alternative Songs chart from February 25 to April 22, 1995. They sold over 20 million albums worldwide.
Over 127,000 people were estimated at the Hard Rock RockFest held at the Atlanta Motor Speedway on Saturday.

The twelve-hour festival featured  the Offspring, Third Eye Blind, Everlast, Eve 6, Sugar Ray, Silverchair, and Collective Soul. And of course Live.. here is a memory of the pit (Not Mosh)...It was HOT and WET ( they kept spraying the hose on us). I was on my feet for  12 hours near the stage. You couldn’t leave and  get back. I was one of the mud people. They showed this on MTV. I could have been on TV because I was down front where the cameras were  I left sunburned and tired. Atlanta in June

Tracklist

01 - Operation Spirit.mp3
02 - All Over You.mp3
03 - Selling The Drama.mp3
04 - Pain Lies On The Riverside.mp3
05 - Turn My Head.mp3
06 - Lakini's Juice.mp3
07 - I Alone.mp3
08 - Lightning Crashes.mp3

A short set but they all were cause it was one after another after another...for 12 hours

Players
  
    Ed Kowalczyk– lead vocals, rhythm guitar (1989–2009, 2016–present)
    Chad Taylor– lead guitar, backing vocals (1989–2009, 2012–present)
    Patrick Dahlheimer– bass (1989–2009, 2012–present)
    Chad Gracey– drums (1989–2009, 2012–present)
    Christopher Thorn– rhythm guitar, backing vocals (1998)
    Adam Kowalczyk– rhythm guitar, backing vocals (1999–2009)
    Michael "Railo" Railton– keyboards, backing vocals (1999–2002)
